reviewText: The art is brilliant and I adore the story for what it is, but the game pacing is unbearable. Character movements are painfully slow, down to the bad voice acting. None of the voice actors seem too interested in actually bringing the story to life, which is a shame, because they could have done The Shopkeeper a lot of justice. When playing I feel trapped as if it were Ground Hog's day, perhaps that was the intention of the developer, but it does not bode well with me. Often I find myself struggling to stay awake while attempting to give an earnest play through. I simply cannot do it. The Shopkeeper had potential for greatness, but unfortunately, I cannot justify anyone spending money on it.
voteText: 85 of 97 people (88%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Having gone through the Groundhog Day like loop that is The Shopkeeper over a dozen times at this point, I'm still struggling to make anything of it.

It's built on ambiguity, giving you only the smallest hints as to context and character motives, as it shifts perspectives at a rapid pace to the extent I'm at a loss to say what is or isn't fiction. And that's interesting and thought provoking, but The Shopkeeper doesn't give you enough to work with to be able to derive any meaning out of its characters or handful of repetitive lines of dialog. As a game stuck on repeat at some point you would assume having seen the sames scenes play out so many times you might eventually grasp what the greater purpose, if there is any, of all this must be. But I never found that moment of clarity, as I continuously attempted to cross dialogue paths while arriving at the same non explanatory ending (for lack of a better term) ad nauseam.

There's something fascinating to me about The Shopkeeper, as if something is hiding just behind the curtain and I've merely failed to procure how exactly to pull it away, but for as far as I can tell these lofty ideas are little more than figments of my imagination conjured up to fill the vast emptiness of the experience. Whether or not my hypothesizing is accurate to any degree I have no way of knowing, but if not, they've concealed the greater explanations and revelations so effectively as they may as well not exist at all.

reviewText:
You play as a shopkeeper desperately trying to sell his merchandise to a ponytailed ♥♥♥♥. How he does this is he makes up a story about the item in question that will appeal to the nature of said ♥♥♥♥.
If you fail to do so he will go away without buying anything only to come back the next day so you can take another crack.

The reason I'm explaining this is so the reader is left with no illusions. I understood the concept and the story, I just didn't think they were adequete. It is a mini-game you would put into a much larger adventure game, not much more. To compare this to either Monkey Island or The Twighlight Zone is making abit of a stretch.

The art is decent, the writing above average, the voice acting isn't brilliant but passable. The fact of the matter is that this isn't much of a game however. There are no puzzles to solve, just a random process of trial and error.
This is a shame. One gets the feeling that the developer could of made something much more.
Hopefully they will in the near future, there is potential.

reviewText:
A lovely short with an interesting story. The Shopkeeper takes a path very close to Dear Esther when it comes to design. The storytelling plays a more important role in the game than the actual gameplay. It took me a while to figure out what the hell was happening in the first place, but after the fog has been lifted I let myself enjoy the little stories.

Needless to say this game is not for everyone. I wouldn't even say that if you liked Dear Esther you will love The Shopkeeper. However for the ones who can overlook the little to no gameplay this 'game' has, it can provide some quality time from a small indie studio. It also has a quite low price tag, so if you are looking for something unusual this might worth to take a look at.

On the other hand, if you are not intrested in any of the above then I would say, just buy a bottle of coke from the money, and enjoy that for the evening, because it is most likely to prove it more worthy for you than this game.

It is not for everyone. But for the few who can enjoy it, it can prove a nice time.

reviewText:
Interactive story-telling is somewhat en-vogue in gaming right now. In a title like The Wolf Among Us or The Walking Dead, for instance, there is a focus on storytelling and decision-making rather than traditional gameplay mechanics. The Shopkeeper takes that idea and pulls back even further in terms of interactivity, becoming a short-form choose your own adventure, where just a handful of different choices will guide the story in one direction or another.

The Shopkeeper presents us with a young businessman looking for an Antique to impress his Mother-in-Law. The titular Shopkeeper tells the story behind each item for sale in his store, and through a series of dialogue choices will explain the consequences of choosing one gift over the other. Pick the incorrect gift and the story will repeat itself, until the correct gift and conversational choices have been made and the credits roll.

The story is very short and simple. Of course, you won’t find the right present right away, so you end up in a sort of Groundhog Day déjà-vu cycle. Although you can only select from a handful of different gifts in the antiques shop, and only around nine different dialogue trees, this still throws up probably thirty or so possible combinations that can played through, and three marginally different endings. Many of the choices won’t change things dramatically, but a minor change in tone or voice, or one different line of dialogue lets you know perhaps you are moving in the right direction.

The problem is that the story is never particularly explicit. Even when the so-called “best” ending is achieved, you can’t really be sure what happened or why that approach was more successful than your previous ones. Being such a short story, you would have hoped that the writing would have been a little tighter and the conversations less nonsensical. This is probably down to the fact that the game must change depending on the combination of choices you have picked, but it feels like there aren’t enough different reactions to what you decide. This results in each subsequent play through feel too repetitive, and it becomes frustrating.

Despite the fact that professional actors with extensive television credits have been used in-game, the delivery is quite poor overall. It all sounds very stunted and at unnatural, which adds to the feeling that each choice and reaction don’t flow together very well. The acting also lacks any real emotion and even when someone might be getting angry or desperate, there is a distinct lack of depth in the vocal work.

The sketchy art style doesn’t really suit the serious and stoic story-telling employed throughout the title, either. The muted colour palette at matches the sombre mood, but the cartoony backgrounds and character models betray the tone of the tale. There is also the inclusion of a notepad for reference, but the notes held within seem to have very little to do with your play through of the game and instead seems to represent the inner monologue of the Shopkeeper himself.

The Shopkeeper is a very uneven experience. Sadly, none of the elements seem to mesh together particularly well. There are also issues with the feeling that most of the choices you make don’t have much impact on the direction of the story. For such a short game where choice is the only real mechanic, your choices need to provide a lot more feedback and actually be significant. Instead, the minor plot differences, disappointing voice acting and sometimes incomprehensible writing combine to create a somewhat frustrating experience. The promised freedom of choice and replayability in this interactive story book is, unfortunately, paper-thin. Overall 4/10.

reviewText:
I typically do not write a review for a game until I've played it for quite a few hours. I may have only played this one for two hours, but I believe I've found everything the game has to offer. And truthfully, I wanted to enjoy it... but I felt I was lost in a story that made little sense and wasn't captivating.

There are also the following core issues:
- The fancy handwritten script can be extremely hard to read.
- There's no option for subtitles. I usually play with audio anyway, but I always dislike it when games /force/ me to have the sound on.
- There's also no music. Music adds so much to a game, or in this case, NOT having it actually takes away from the experience.

The achievements were also mostly based on repetition; the game had to be completed twenty or thirty times to get everything, and even then, there was little to no guidance on how to get the achievements, so it was mostly me stumbling around blindly clicking on things and hoping an achievement unlocks.

There are some high points, like the voice acting -- it's not great, or even good, but I've also heard much worse. The concept is also cool, though the storyline could have been fleshed out more. It doesn't even do it justice to storylines to SAY this game has a storyline, as it's mostly random tidbits of information about items in a fictional shop coupled with a minorly interesting, not-that-compelling dialogue between The Customer and his Mother-in-Law. Overall, I don't think I can really recommend this game, but if you insist on buying it, I recommend checking out the achievement guide I wrote in the guides section, mostly because it will limit the amount of frustrating repetition that is to be found in this game.

reviewText:
The Shopkeeper is a short point and click game with many similarities to a visual novel. The game is very brief, with a playthrough taking around 2 minutes. The full story is learned through multiple playthroughs, which could take about 30-45 minutes overall.

The gameplay in The Shopkeeper is minimal. You are immediately thrown into the story, without much idea what is going on. You can click on items to learn more about them, and also click on responses while you are talking to your Mother-in-law. After a round or two you will kind of get the gist of what you have to accomplish. There are about 4 total scenes, and you will not see every one on each playthrough. Once a round is over, you are thrown right back to the beginning of the story to start again. Eventually, you will achieve the desired result through your clicking and will see the ending.

The graphics look pleasing, but there was very little to create between the handful of scenes. The sound, voice acting in particular, is bordering on the line between grating and unbearable.  Lucky the game is short, because I probably would have had to turn it off just due to the voice acting alone in another few minutes.

I cannot recommend The Shopkeeper. Although it is already offered at a low price, current $3, it just doesn't seem worth it. I spent a rather unenjoyable 30 minutes with this game, and would advise you to avoid doing the same.

Grade: D

reviewText: Keep in mind that this is not the sort of point&click game where you can move around freely (the game does that for you) plus there are no puzzles in a traditional sense. It's probably more like a short third person audiobook with very light interactive elements, where you are able to click on a couple of objects and dialogue choices, but except for that the game dictates everything else. If you're okay with that, you can expect interesting artwork and a very nice and dark comedy, that can actually get you thinking!

reviewText:
I think I like what this game was trying to do, but unfortunately, the execution was lacking. I can feel the potential, and I really wanted to like it.

The interactivity is almost non-existant, and what's there is poorly implemented. Clicking on things usually had no effect, even when the cursor changed, making me think that there was some interaction with the object the mouse was over. Sometimes, clicking would inexplicably skip dialog, making me miss things, other times, nothing would happen. The game appeared to keep going regardless of what I did, and the events in the game rarely had anything to do with the things I clicked on.

Overall, this left me feeling confused and frustrated.

reviewText: Short but sweet gem of a game. The art is original and well executed, and the voice acting very good. It is not so much a puzzle or adventure game as a story exploration game. The central puzzle is there as a raison d'être, but the game is more about contemplation and atmosphere - playing it just for the challenge would likely have you missing much of what makes it beautiful. My only complaint is that it is very short, but the format seems open to more visitors to the shop in the future.

reviewText: This is the absolute worst and most tedious point-and-click adventure I have ever even seen, let alone played. I stuck with it, for the sake of getting all the achievements, but that is not exactly a strong draw for encouragement to play, and I was about to quit when the final one finally was awarded. I got this in a bundle, and I still feel cheated. If you don't play for the sake of achievements, you will almost certainly be bored and quit within ten minutes, which is how long it takes to more than get the gist of what is going on. It could have been better, had the focus actually been on creating an engrossing story, but instead you just visit the same scenes and hear the same messages over and over again, with the opportunity to click a new item in the shop to hear about every few minutes or so, before then speed-clicking your way through the same cut-scenes and dialogue screens all over again until you get back to the shop to click another item to hear about. That right there is basically the entirety of the game, and with a nonsense story you won't care about to go along with it.

reviewText:
The Shopkeeper is a point and click game which tries to lead you through a short story about a man trying to find a gift for his difficult and wealthy mother-in-law. He knows where to look, the local antique shop, but does not know what to buy. The Shopkeeper however knows the story behind each of his items, and the outcome of choosing incorrectly turns out the same way each time; with a dismissal from the mother-in-law style repetition of these events.

Game: 2.0/10
Graphic: 4.5/10

reviewText: I bought it straight away because it was recommended by the 'choices and consequences' curator. While said choices are indeed present in the game, I failed to see any logic in how your actions affected the outcome of the game. Yes, you get to click a bunch of antique stuff and hear the snippets of the item's story, then you have some dialogue choices. But what good is the choice if its concequence is completely random and unrelated? Don't get me wrong, it's not like the concequence is so surprising that you can't even see how exactly you got to it. It's just that the concequence doesn't make any sense or have any relation to the choice you made so you start to wonder if your decision making even mattered. That's what annoyed me the most and that's why I regretted spending any amount of money on this game. Also, the structure of the game is very bizarre. I couldn't figure out exactly at what point one playthrough ended and the next one started because the game starts anew automatically. Maybe I'm just too dumb but I still think game developers should've done a better job of marking the beginning of each playthrough and overall explaining ♥♥♥♥ to the player. This particular player felt frustrated and annoyed by the lack of logic or at least the explanation of what's going on. Dislike.

reviewText:
The Shopkeeper is a short, confusing, repetitive, obliquous game with a pretty bad voice acting with no subtitles to make the comprehension easier.

The game presents us with a young businessman looking for an antique to gift and impress his Mother-in-Law. The titular Shopkeeper tells the story behind each item for sale in his store and through a series of dialogue choices, it will be explained the consequences of choosing one gift over the other. Pick the incorrect gift and the story will repeat itself, until you pick the right one and the game ends.

The problem is that the story is never particularly explicit. Even when the best ending is achieved, you can’t really be sure what happened or why that approach was more successful than your previous ones. This results in each subsequent play through feel too repetitive and it becomes frustrating... very frustrating.

reviewText:
Don't be deceived. This game has little to no interaction, and it's dull. Dull. DULL.

1.Pick an object. The shopkeeper muses on it. Or don't. You can just wait until the customer comes in.
2.Pick an object. The shopkeeper tells the customer a story about it, which has a few dialogue choices.
3.The customer decides whether or not to buy the item.
4. Go to 1.

That's it. That's the entire game. It might have been just about bearable, but the endless repetition of dialogue is abominable. Prepare to hear the same phrases repeated over and over and over again. The voice acting is atrocious as well, with none of the cast sounding like they could be bothered.

Which ever item you pick, the story" is exactly the same except for one or two lines of dialogue

reviewText: This game really is god awful. The only real challenge is in unlocking all of the achievements, and challenge is putting it mildly. In reality, it's just annoying. But, in a little over an hour, I did it. The different angles that you start the game from are annoying because you have no choice, which means there's no efficient way to complete the achievements, which are really the only game part of the game. The whole game is repetitive, but especially the dialog. If choosing different items in the shop and in the office actually led to completely different dialog, the game might be alright. But, given that no matter what choices you make, you'll hear essentially the same audio, it's pointless to have to repeat the game over and over again. The artwork is fine. The voice acting is fine. But the gameplay is horrible.

reviewText:
The Shopkeeper is a short story, point and click game in which you will step into the shoes of someone who needs to buy a present for his rich mother in law, hoping to impress her and eventually receive money through a business offer.

The game itself is a slow paced, repetitive, and it's annoying replay system in which you have to select multiple shop items to hear their little story in which you will gather information about the outcome  of giving  that gift.

As this is a short story, point and click game i think it should be treated for what it is, not anything fancy, no interaction whatsoever, no subtitles, no freedom at all, you can listen to a dialogue of different items,a small dialogue selection with your mother in law, and that's all, with a beautiful short story.

I recommend it when it's on a bundle or a good sale price, for a couple hours of casual clicking and listening to a short story i think it would be worth it.

reviewText: This might be the glitchiest game I've ever played.\n\nThe goal and controls aren't self-explanatory, and there's no tutorial. The only options in the Options" menu are for resizing the screen
recommended: and exiting the game. I've played for over half an hour and the gameplay still doesn't make any sense--I can never know when to expect the game will go to what scene or what I'm supposed to do in a scene to make things progress in a new way. Every area has a time limit. Exploration seems to be discouraged because you have only seconds to look around any given screen before the default dialogue for that location starts. The game also restarts itself again and again without prompting when you get to the end
hoursPlayed: which is never clarified as being the end.\n\nThe "Notes" don't help you figure out how to get different endings--they're just flavor text from what I've seen--and this game could really use some kind of hint system so the player won't be forced to use trial and error just to learn the game mechanics. You can't control the movement of any of the characters. The very few offered dialogue prompts are in only one scene
voteText: and they're as unintuitive as any of the other mechanics. The only hints I can give as to the gameplay are that clicking on an object in the antique store and getting its long story can sometimes effect the dialogue you get when you return to the store
helpfulPercent: but not always; and that clicking on an object in the mother-in-law's office can occasionally give you a different ending scene if you pick the right dialogue path.\n\nI've found none of the four characters to be likeable--the mother-in-law seems to have no positive dialogue paths that paint her as a likable person
votesHelpful: the son-in-law is a failure and/or a jerk in every dialogue path he has
votesTotal: the gardener only has unkind things to say about someone he barely knows
votesFunny: and the antique shop owner doesn't have a lot of personality and is more of a storytelling device than a person--his only bit of backstory that I've found was from the gardener and the line had more personality than the antique dealer. The animations are jerky. The one true ending I've found had a cutscene that faded to black
column16: went on to a scene that explained what happened
column17: and ended with two scenes that didn't make any sense with the context.\n\nThe only positive thing I can think to say about this game is that the longer stories about the antiques are interesting
column18: but good luck being able to trigger one. If you miss your chance at a long story you need to wait for the game to cycle through the mother-in-law area again; and
column20: you aren't guaranteed to end up back inside the antique shop. You could end up outside and have to wait for the game to play through again and hope you're not outside this time. Even if you do end up back in the shop after the mother-in-law scene they might talk about a different antique than the one you chose at first regardless of whether you got a long story.\n\nI got this game in a Humble Bundle and gave it a shot. I would not recommend going out of your way to purchase this game. It is barely playable and not enjoyable in its current state."

reviewText: I'm going to recommend thus game with one small caveat. If you get it, beware of playing for too long and be aware that there's little to no replay value AND a  short playtime...\n\nThat being said, this is a pretty good game in the end. Not as good as the description up top would have you believe, but still good, still worth a look if you like story-driven indies. There's a lot of room for improvement (such as making the item indicator/selector AND items themselves easier to see) but what there is to the game is a solid start.

reviewText:
I do not recomend this game. But if you have it, it's a good option for a fast perfect game (achievements).

Here's why: The game is utterly confusing and repetitive, where your choices change very little, from he choice of an item in the shop to the furniture in the office. The storylines are repetitive and therefore dull after the first time seen. Getting to the right answer only takes luck and a lot of patience but has nothing to do with your choice or it being a rational conversation either.

As for the User Experience I would rate it terrible, choices in the game are arbitrarily arranged and follow no order, you can't choose the way you enter the shop (bad because some of the ways choose the item in the story for you) and the notes are scribbles that sometimes can't even be read

I finished the game with all achievements in ~100min (some people played even less), but luckily I got this game in a bundle so as I view it, was free. Also...if you like achievements and have the game, here's a good oportunity for a perfect game, eventhough it's a really bad one (it only has 10 achivements).

reviewText:
I tried to write a review for this title a few days ago when I got it, and was unable to. I only wish Steam fixes this problem in the future so others can see the reviews of horrible games like this, before they pay for them.

Since it is too late for me, I want everyone else to know that this game is actually the worst I have ever played.

It is not a point and click adventure as the story goes on without your input.

The story doesn't have a clear end, as the man will always come back to the store, but seemingly for the first time,   even if the layout is a bit different.

The stories told by the shopkeeper are also confusing. The main character of his story is obviously not the man in the shop, and yet the story seems to outline what will happen to the man upon returning to speak to his mother in law and looks exactly like the man in the shop.

Also nothing in the story the shopkeeper tells has anything to do with the actual artifact the man is asking about, or not asking about, depending on if you just let the game play itself or not.

In short: if this game were free, I would still not want it in my Steam library, because it would remind me of the time I wasted on it.

reviewText: Sometimes, the indie-game-world produces amazing games. They can be minimal, they can be short, they can have bad voice-overs or bad music. A game just needs to be fun, or at the very least, entertaining in some way. The Shopkeeper" fails in every possible way.\n\nSimply put
date: the game is boring. This is a point-and-click adventure game with
hoursPlayed: 5 screens to explore. Gameplay revolves around a short story that repeats ad infinitum. (It's a bit like the movie
voteText: "Groundhog's Day"
helpfulPercent: except really short and uninteresting.) You have no control over your character. (It isn't even clear who your character is supposed to be.) There are only 6 characters in the story. Two of them
votesHelpful: will never interact with you. Clicking on items will sometimes give an explanation... and sometimes it won't.\n\n...and... that's about it for gameplay. Oh
votesTotal: there is ONE dialog tree. Most of the time
votesFunny: the dialog doesn't change. You have to pick the correct item AND the correct dialog options in one run. Make a mistake? You must play through the entire sequence to start over.\n\nThe graphics are quaint
commentsCount: but poor. If all I'm going to see in a game are 5 screens
column16: those screens should look amazing. Instead
column17: we mostly have neutral tones of brown and gray.\n\nThis isn't a game
column18: it's a story. A non-interactive story that provides choices but punishes you for making the incorrect decision. It just isn't fun. This is a really bad way to tell me a story."

reviewText:
To be honest, I had high hopes about this game.

After playing this game for 2 hours, I feel like I wasted my time. This game is an endless loop, with only a slightly different ending after each conversation.

This game made me want to go to sleep with the boring voice repeating the same words over and over again with each run through.

I would not recommend this game, and I hope you will spend your money elsewhere, as this game is not even worth a price other than free.

reviewText:
The Shopkeeper ReviewA game I shouldn't be wasting my time reviewing.

The Shopkeeper is truly something awful. Upon my first playthrough, I was positive that this was going to be a fantastic game. The artwork was the first thing I saw and it is definitely beautiful! But nevertheless it is the only thing good about this game...

You play the same five minute story over and over again and there's no stopping point. To be honest, I've only played it for a decent amount of time to get the achievements. But I can barely survive a playthrough without falling asleep or crying of boredom. The voice actors are also awful and so is the storyline. I was hoping for this to be a great game, and I predict that it could of been. But no, don't be fooled by the astounding artwork. This game was a complete disappointment.

reviewText: With only 12% positive reviews (22.05.2015) it is a major incident I had played this game and you know what: it was great! Some of the main reasons people do no like this game are the following:\nPeople have the wrong expectations: The store description says point and click narrative (not adventure), but also mentions Classic Lucas Arts Productions (which is indeed wrong).\nPeople seem to be too stupid to understand what this game is about and where the focus lies (Fitting citation: lost in a story without sense"): Lots haven't seen the right ending
date: which is eminent to the understanding. They are angry about the ever repeating sentences - but those are varying in little parts to supplement to the story (the Groundhog setting). And the playtime is short
recommended: about 3-5 minutes per try - but you will play it more than you will expect to get to the right ending!The game is not as simple as it seems: There are lots of situations where the perspective is shifting (from the shopkeeper to the customer and back); the short playtime of 3 minutes per visit is really fitting to represent the setting as a hopeless scenery for the customer; all the objects in the game contribute with their little background stories to the whole
hoursPlayed: involving macabre stories. And yes - there are no subtitles: but if you don't understand the whole conversation
voteText: it's not a big problem; wait 3 minutes and the story begins again ...\n\nWell
helpfulPercent: what's the conclusion: If you like a small point and click visual novel with a nice art-style
votesTotal: an indie game with well done voice acting
votesFunny: where you try to buy an old antique for your mother-in-law in order to let her sponsor your business
commentsCount: then it's worth a try.\nBe prepared for a bad-tempered mother-in-law
column16: a marked-by-life shopkeeper and a family tragedy with a surprising end (the right one!)!\n\nGame has achievements (some are hidden)
column18: the playtime is around 1-2 hours; if you manage to figure out the right end at your first playthrough
column19: you are done in 5 minutes!\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nFor all gamers with niveau and courage to give it a try despite of all the negative reviews!"

reviewText: OK lots of thumbs down and here's another but this game is not *just* junk, I believe it's about something" in the way that most student short films are "about something" and it does contain thought provoking ideas and some sort of emotional payload. However
date: there is very little "content" here and many problems with the way the ideas have been implemented and packaged as a for-money videogame.\n\nIf you've seen the movie Groundhog Day
recommended: imagine a version of that which is 5 minutes long with only about 5 camera shots and instead of being about learning how to be a great human being
hoursPlayed: the story's about Bill Murray having to guess the correct gift-object to give to his crush out of a choice of maybe a dozen. (And spoilers
voteText:
no happy ending.)

Or The Stanley Parable with 2% of the content.

Factor in some amateur voice acting
votesHelpful: a short background ambient sound which fades out and back in at each repeat instead of looping seamlessly
votesTotal: forced repetition of conversations that even the developer tells us to skip and literally one puzzle to solve: which hotspot do you click on at which time and which of the possible paths do you take through a 3-level dialogue tree?\n\nAll of the "Achievements" can only be won by brute force random clicking
votesFunny: while the game tells you aloud that you suck and chose poorly every couple of minutes and punishes you with the exact same 3 choices and audio clips for the Nth time.\n\nTo make things worse
commentsCount: for me it seems buggy. The scene would change back to the start room and the customer would complain that an object I hadn't even clicked on was totally wrong for him. Then I'd get an Achievement.\n\nHaving "won" (after more than an hour) it seems the secret message is about *not wasting our precious time* but I feel this minigame does just that and for very little reward. Glad it came "free" in a Humble Bundle. There are many nice things in how it was made and I look forward to the creators' next

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game to anybody.

the whole design is borderline confusing already at the main menu. al the text around the game is hand-written, which could have been a nice intuition, if it wasn't for the terrible calligraphy. I had a hard time even understanding the dial to lower the volume.

the voice acting is boring and irritating, especially since it is so obvious the actors are pretending to be some highborn fancy-talking VIP, which makes them to my eyes very distant that I couldn't relate or impersonate with any of them.

also, the story really makes no sense. there are unexpected and unannounced flashbacks that makes it difficult to follow the story along, creating confusion on the who and when.

also, there's not much to do in the game rather than following the story, which has all the flaws I've exposed above.

one last thing: the absence of subtitles is UNFORGIVABLE.

reviewText: I don't often throw around the phrase waste of time
date:
but in this case, it's all too appropriate.  Although the artistic style is interesting, that's the only positive I can offer for this game - other than that the story is mercifully very short.

How short?

A man enters an antique shop to buy a present for his mother-in-law.  Then the man has a conversation about business and family with said mother-in-law.

That's it.  You've completed the game.

You then return to the beginning to play through it again, in case you have literally nothing else to do.  This wouldn't feel like such a punishment if, say, the animation and voice-over work were anything but horrible, or if the conversation led anywhere interesting.  Instead, the game succeeds only at being a decent simulation of rooting through garbage for a prize that isn't there.
hoursPlayed: false

reviewText:
It's such a shame when a game with such an interesting premise is let down by its execution.
The art is hauntingly apt for the thin narrative, desperately flickering through the shallow interface and the board voice acting.
The worst part of this is the knowledge that a writer with more skill, or a games designer with more experience would have been able to deliver a powerful piece of work from the ingredients offered here.
This game needed to run for much longer and in a fashion not so frustratingly linear, that way it may have had a chance, however small, to grow on the player through sheer curiosity.
As it stands, the only curiosity that can be satisfied by this game is that of bile.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The Shopkeeper sports a surreal tale where a man is looking for an antique object to try and impress his rich mother-in-law: you'll get to hear the story behind each object and see the consequences of your choice.
Sadly this interesting concept is ruined by shallow and repetitive gameplay and a story that simply isn't interesting.

PROS:

-the hand drawn graphics are quite nice

-decently ambigue and surreal atmosphere

-fully voice acted

CONS:

-trial and error gameplay gets boring fast

-extremely short, each game session lasts about 5 minutes (before you either get an ending or have to restart)

-characters lack depth

-voice acting is pretty awful due to the flat, emotionless tone all characters have

-the whole story simply fails to be engaging or interesting enough

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=486198794

Gameplay in The Shopkeeper sadly boils down to this, pick an object, see the effect it has on your mother-in-law when paired with your choices and either get an ending or find yourself teleported again in the shop as if nothing had happened. You're basically just trying different combinations until you find one that gets you an ending and that's all there is to it: you can see how it gets dull fast.

Sadly the story doesn't fare any better due to the characters having little background or depth: this means you'll find it quite hard to care what happens to the client or her mother-in-law since you'll never have a connection to them.

The Shopkeeper is sadly not good enough as a game or even an interactive story to recommend.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Usually I don’t refund games when they are bad, only when they are broken or don’t work properly (anymore). In this case I did it even when I didn’t pay much during the winter sale.
The Shopkeeper has a neat premise but the execution is horrible. There is not much here but the repetition of the same sequences of three screens with the same short and uninspired lines of dialogue. The gameplay consists of nothing than clicking some random objects, listening to the same repetitive dialogues and waiting for some random achievements to pop up. There’s neither an enjoyable game nor any meaning or engaging story to witness here. It starts boring and continues being it with no hope for getting something out of the experience, as the game pretty much goes on on its own with the player only clicking randomly on the screen.

Furthermore, the game mechanics just don’t work in the way they seem to be meant. They won’t be explained in any way and therefore you are thrown into the game without anything useful to do and trying to figure out, what there is to do. Unfortunately, there IS nothing to do, really.
On top of that, the dialogues are dreadfully written and the voice acting is not very good. Also there are no subtitles which would be very useful. (Note for these las sentences that I am not a native English speaker and therefore have a blurry look on this topic).

The art style is neat but gets wasted in the three screens that come over and over again. So the art style gets boring very fast and very undeserved.

It is a shame to give this game a bad review seen what it could be, that it looks relatively good and that the premises gameplay and story wise are interesting. But as bad as the execution is, it is needed.
Get this game in case you feel lucky or very intrigued. There are people who seemed to enjoy it very much. And in case you won’t like it, you can always refund it.

The gameplay consists of nothing than clicking some random objects, listening to the same repetitive dialogues and waiting for some random achievements to pop up. There’s neither an enjoyable game nor any meaning or engaging story to witness here. It starts boring and continues being it with no hope for getting something out of the experience, as the game pretty much goes on on its own with the player only clicking randomly on the screen.

Furthermore, the game mechanics just don’t work in the way they seem to be meant. They won’t be explained in any way and therefore you are thrown into the game without anything useful to do and trying to figure out, what there is to do. Unfortunately, there IS nothing to do, really.
On top of that, the dialogues are dreadfully written and the voice acting is not very good. Also there are no subtitles which would be very useful. (Note for these las sentences that I am not a native English speaker and therefore have a blurry look on this topic).

The art style is neat but gets wasted in the three screens that come over and over again. So the art style gets boring very fast and very undeserved.

It is a shame to give this game a bad review seen what it could be, that it looks relatively good and that the premises gameplay and story wise are interesting. But as bad as the execution is, it is needed.
Get this game in case you feel lucky or very intrigued. There are people who seemed to enjoy it very much. And in case you won’t like it, you can always refund it.

reviewText:
The Shopkeeper sports a surreal tale where a man is looking for an antique object to try and impress his rich mother-in-law: you'll get to hear the story behind each object and see the consequences of your choice.
Sadly this interesting concept is ruined by shallow and repetitive gameplay and a story that simply isn't interesting.

PROS:

-the hand drawn graphics are quite nice

-decently ambigue and surreal atmosphere

-fully voice acted

CONS:

-trial and error gameplay gets boring fast

-extremely short, each game session lasts about 5 minutes (before you either get an ending or have to restart)

-characters lack depth

-voice acting is pretty awful due to the flat, emotionless tone all characters have

-the whole story simply fails to be engaging or interesting enough

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=486198794

Gameplay in The Shopkeeper sadly boils down to this, pick an object, see the effect it has on your mother-in-law when paired with your choices and either get an ending or find yourself teleported again in the shop as if nothing had happened. You're basically just trying different combinations until you find one that gets you an ending and that's all there is to it: you can see how it gets dull fast.

Sadly the story doesn't fare any better due to the characters having little background or depth: this means you'll find it quite hard to care what happens to the client or her mother-in-law since you'll never have a connection to them.

The Shopkeeper is sadly not good enough as a game or even an interactive story to recommend.

reviewText:
The asthetic of the game is unique to indie titles. Sadly too common within that genre.

The game plays as a point-and-click adventure. Slowed by only allowing you to select 3 items before an elaborate and familiar conversation or two before the day starts anew. A tutorial wouldn't go amiss, minecraft pulled it off. The Shopkeeper, not so much.

Let my small play-time tell you this, I have every achivement, I have entierly finished the game. Read every sign, saw every coversation and while the story is somewhat interesting I find myself struggling to list worse games.

reviewText: The game is straight up terrible. The only reason to buy it is for achievements, because if you're patient you're not gonna have any problems getting all of them. It's no challenge at all, and it'll take you about an hour or two. But otherwise, the game is ♥♥♥♥ing terrible, should be treated as trash, and don't buy it, unless in a bundle (like me), or in a huge sale.\nThe story is good, and if it wouldn't take so ♥♥♥♥ing long to narrate it, the game would be bearable. Like this - it's not.\n1/10
